Causal Inference in Statistics #

Questions #

  • Why is the causal effect identifiable in an IV DAG when the dependencies are linear (from an SCM perspective)?
    • I think this may relate to factor models.

Advanced Data Analysis from an Elementary Point of View (Ch. 18-23) #

Chapter 18 #

Exercises #

18.2. Proof that every path must go through a collider:

Observe that every path between two exogenous variables starts with variables going in the opposite direction. Thus, if we imagine walking the path from one exogenous variable to another, we see that the direction of the arrows has to switch at a node, which will be a collider.

item.title: Paper Review - IVs and Mendelian Randomization
item.description:
Summary #

Detailed Notes #

3 IV Requirements #

  1. IV must have a direct influence on the treatment
  2. IV must not covary with the unmeasured confounding that impacts the outcome
  3. IV must not have a direct influence on the outcome

Relevant considerations for deciding whether to do an IV analysis #

  • Is there any unmeasured confounding?

    • If not, is the answer that we can just use a normal regression?

  • When is unmeasured confounding especially likely?
